text:
Raskolnikov was unsure of what he was doing. 

“I might bring you something else soon, Alyona Ivanovna—a valuable thing—silver—a cigarette box, as soon as I get it back from a friend…” he stopped, feeling awkward.

“Well, we can talk about it then,” she replied.

“Goodbye—are you always home alone? Is your sister not here with you?” he asked casually as he stepped into the hallway.

“What’s it to you, sir?” she answered.

“Oh, nothing special, I just asked. You’re too quick to respond… Good day, Alyona Ivanovna.”

Raskolnikov left feeling very confused. His confusion grew as he went down the stairs, stopping a few times as if he suddenly remembered something. Once outside, he shouted, “Oh, God, this is all awful! Can I really… No, that’s nonsense, it’s crazy!” he said firmly. “How could I even think of such a terrible thing? My heart is capable of such filthy thoughts. Yes, filthy and disgusting! For a whole month, I’ve been…”

He couldn’t find the right words to express how upset he felt. The strong feeling of disgust that had started to weigh on him while he was going to see the old woman had grown so strong that he didn’t know how to escape his misery. He walked down the street like he was drunk, bumping into people and not caring about them.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences intense confusion and repulsion after a troubling encounter with Alyona Ivanovna, reflecting on the dark thoughts that have plagued him.
